citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure pen that houses one adult male capybara, two African crowned cranes, an adult black swan,
seven adult bar-headed geese, an adult Muscovy duck and 17 adult domestic ducks has an area without a public barrier,
between the primate house and the edge of the pond; there are also some areas where the grid paneling that serves as a
public barrier is missing or has gaps through which the public can potentially have direct contact with the animals inside.
Public barriers are important to protect both the animals and people; people or animals can be injured by unauthorized
direct contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must
ensure that there is sufficient distance and barriers of sufficient height and integrity in good repair between the animals
and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals and the public.

There are two adult male lemurs ("Ziptie", 23 years old and "Wilbur", 18 years old) housed in enclosures with peeling paint
on the walls.
Surfaces with peeling paint cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized, and pose a risk of animal illness due to ingestion of
peeled paint. The licensee must ensure that all surfaces are maintained on a regular basis to facilitate cleaning and to
prevent animal illness.
TO BE CORRECTED BY DECEMBER 4, 2023

In the area near the outdoor enclosures housing two adult North American black bears and two adult wolves, there is a
large pile of dry, brown conifer type trees discarded on the ground.
Discarded trash and other materials such as dead brush and trees that accumulate on the grounds near animal
enclosures can pose a fire hazard and harbor pests and vermin that can cause animal illness and/or injury. The licensee
must ensure that premises, buildings and grounds are kept clean and in good repair; accumulations of trash/debris should
be cleared as necessary to protect the health and safety of the animals.
TO BE CORRECTED BY DECEMBER 22, 2023

Accumulations of rat droppings are seen on the floor in the backquarters portion of an exhibit housing one adult male
South American tapir. A live adult rat was seen inside the space occupied by the tapir and within a piece of plastic conduit
inside the indoor portion of the enclosure. There were no rodent traps inside the building at the time of inspection.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests
in animal areas.
TO BE CORRECTED BY JANUARY 4, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
The primary enclosure pen that houses one adult male capybara, two African crowned cranes, an adult black swan, 
seven adult bar-headed  geese, an adult Muscovy duck and 17 adult domestic ducks has an area without a public barrier, 
between the primate house and the edge of the pond; there are also some areas where the grid paneling that serves as a 
public barrier is missing or has gaps through which the public can potentially have direct contact with the animals inside.  
Public barriers are important to protect both the animals and people; people or animals can be injured by unauthorized 
direct contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must 
ensure that there is sufficient distance and barriers of sufficient height and integrity in good repair between the animals 
and the general viewing  public so as to assure the safety of animals and the public. 
3.75(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are two adult male lemurs ("Ziptie", 23 years old and "Wilbur", 18 years old) housed in enclosures with peeling paint 
on the walls.  
Surfaces with peeling paint cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized, and pose a risk of animal illness due to ingestion of 
peeled paint. The licensee must ensure that all surfaces are maintained on a regular basis to facilitate cleaning and to 
prevent animal illness. 
TO BE CORRECTED  BY DECEMBER 4, 2023 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the area near the outdoor enclosures housing two adult North American black bears and two adult wolves, there is a 
large pile of dry, brown conifer type trees discarded on the ground.  
Discarded trash and other materials such as dead brush and trees that accumulate on the grounds near animal 
enclosures can pose a fire hazard and harbor pests and vermin that can cause animal illness and/or injury. The licensee 
must ensure that premises, buildings and grounds are kept clean and in good repair; accumulations of trash/debris should 
be cleared as necessary to protect the health and safety of the animals. 
TO BE CORRECTED  BY DECEMBER 22, 2023

3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Accumulations of rat droppings are seen on the floor in the backquarters portion of an exhibit housing one adult male 
South American tapir. A live adult rat was seen inside the space occupied by the tapir and within a piece of plastic conduit 
inside the indoor portion of the enclosure. There were no rodent traps inside the building at the time of inspection. 
A safe and effective  program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be 
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests 
in animal areas.  
TO BE CORRECTED  BY JANUARY 4, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
